jyoshu

It's amazing how much you don't want to talk about is "extranneous" to the conversation.
 
 If you don't want to discuss it, that's fine. It proves a point unto itself.

 
 Yeah, it proves I prefer to stay on topic.
 
 
Of course you "think" that.
 You have nothing that actually CONDEMNS polygamy, so OF COURSE you can't admit that...

 
 Please don't lie. I've already told you I know there's nothing "condemning" polygamy--I told you more that once now I never claimed it was 'condemned.'
 
 
THIS is an example of your deceit.
 I am not "refuting" anything you "didn't say".
 I am confirming one of the points that I SAID.
 The fact that you aren't refuting my point is irrelevant.
 You keep trying to make me talking about a point that I MADE an issue about you, when I never claimed it was about you.

 
 Foundit, that's not deceit on my part. It's just that you apparently like to interject a lot of extra stuff, and I'm starting to realize that about you.
 
 
Just because the Bible tells deacons how to act DOES NOT mean it's telling EVERYBODY to act that way...
 ... and if we acknowledge that it's not telling everybody to act that way, then it IS NOT saying that it is okay for everybody to act otherwise.
 
 It IS SILENT on the issue.
 Do you get that? Do you know what "silence" means?

 
 Apparently, you are absolutely incapable of thinking in terms of anything other than pure black and white. To you, a specification to one group (deacons) means a full license to commit whatever else anyone wants to for non-deacons! 
 
 Are you able to understand that concept of moral standards? It's not about saying WHO GETS TO DO WHAT; it's about a standard and that deacons should aspire to the higher standard!
 
 Geez.
 
 And you keep expecting me to show you OVER and OVER wher polygamy is CONDEMNED in the Bible and I HAVE TOLD YOU I NEVER SAID IT WASN'T. I DON'T DISAGREE WITH YOU THAT IT'S NOT SPECIFICALLY CONDEMNED. Apparently, that has to be spelled out for you verbatim. 
 
 Holy cow. emoticon_xdonno Unbelieveable.
foundit66

Sure, the extremely minority view. 
 Just like there's an extremely minority view that thinks Jesus and Mary Magdalene had something going. If you prefer interpretations that require speculation and isogesis to come to conclusions that's your choice.

 That would pretty much define the Sodom and Gomorrah pretense that it's about "homosexuality"...
 With the exception that it's the "majority" view.
 Do you condemn people who make that speculation as well?
 
 
 
I'd say BOTH are examples of isogesis. Ironically, you're following in the footsteps of those translators of Genesis 19 by reading homosexuality into the passage.

 Quite frankly, if I were going to use something to "condemn" a group of people, I wouldn't base it on speculation.
 And I admit that my comments are speculatory.
 Do the translators of Genesis 19 do the same?
 
 
 
The context is the rest of the passage--that he was giving him gifts--his costly royal gear and expensive royal apparel. Did you read the rest of it?

 If you give clothes to Goodwill, do you typically wear them to the store to strip right in front of the staff.
 
 
 
And again, kissing (as well as hugging and handholding) is much, much more common in middle-eastern and African societies among males. It doesn't mean something sexual. Judas kissed Christ as well. What you are not getting is that the Bible is very explicit in stating the actions and feelings of David (take the Bathsheba passage for example)--if he had been sexually attracted to Jonathan, it would have come out and said so. It wouldn't be a veiled implication.

 < snort <
 You REALLY are not getting the big picture about gays in history, are you...
 It's often "veiled" in some accounts, when other accounts are quite explicit as to what happened.
 
 
 
And for that matter, the Bathsheba passage pretty much puts the bed any idea that David was gay.

 Did I say David was gay?
 Have you ever heard of "bisexual"?
 
 
 
I don't get how it is that you ascertain that means David and Jonathan were gay.

 Have you ever read some of the posts around here (and other boards) about theories on why people are gay???
 The old "oppressive mother / absent father causes homosexuality" routine?
 
 
 
Only for someone who reads something sexual into non-sexual things.

 I admit that it COULD BE platonic or it COULD BE romantic.
 I think it would be more accurate to say FOR YOU "Only for someone who excludes things sexual from professions of 'love'".
 
 
 
Yeah sure Foundit, they were just gettin' nekkid and gettin' it on. Whatever. emoticon_rolleyes He was giving his gear and royal garments (worth a LOT) as gifts. And did you not read the parts of the passage where David calls him his "brother"? 

 He told his FATHER they were brothers.
 Have you ever heard of gay people referring to their partner as a "room-mate"? 
 
 
 
Well that pretty much shows me once and for all that you have not made any effort whatsoever to take cultural context into account with the passage, nor separate it from our context.

 So, do you have any friends of a culture where this is acceptable?
 And why is it that the rest of the Bible doesn't describe things like this amongst "friends"? At least not to the levels discussed in these chapters...
 
 I acknowledge "cultural context".
 The point is that it does not EXCLUDE what I am talking about either...
 
 
 
And like I said, maybe you'd need to be straight to understand how deep two guys can be close friends (and not be gay), like brothers.

 Yeah. You said it.
 It was ignorant the first time, and it's ignorant the second time.
 I can understand how two men can be close friends in a non-homosexual relationship, and be like brothers.
 
 The issue is not me excluding that as a possibility.
 But of course, you dishonestly portray it as that.
 I guess THAT should be expected...
foundit66

Yeah, it proves I prefer to stay on topic.

 You prefer to stay on the topic that's convenient for you.
 That much is obvious, as again and again you drop discussion and refuse to discuss things that you cannot defend.
 
 
 
Please don't lie. I've already told you I know there's nothing "condemning" polygamy--I told you more that once now I never claimed it was 'condemned.'

 WHERE did you tell me *I know there's nothing "condemning" polygamy*???
 
 
 
Foundit, that's not deceit on my part. It's just that you apparently like to interject a lot of extra stuff, and I'm starting to realize that about you.

 Gee. I talk about stuff. All types of stuff. Even "extra" stuff, as you put it...
 Oooh. Alert the cops!
 emoticon_wow 
 
 
Apparently, you are absolutely incapable of thinking in terms of anything other than pure black and white. To you, a specification to one group (deacons) means a full license to commit whatever else anyone wants to for non-deacons!

 I am capable of thinking in things LOGICALLY.
 The same can't be said of you...
 A specification of requirements FOR DEACONS is a specification of requirements FOR DEACONS.
 If the same requirements, or other requirements, are to be made of the general population, then those requirements should be listed ELSEWHERE.
 
 As is your usual lack of style, you have resorted to hyperbole to try and rebuff my point.
 I'm not talking about "a full license to commit whatever else anyone wants".
 But if it is NOT SPECIFICALLY condemned for the general population, and directives are ONLY given for deacons, then the general population is free to follow or NOT FOLLOW those directives...
 
 
 
Are you able to understand that concept of moral standards? It's not about saying WHO GETS TO DO WHAT; it's about a standard and that deacons should aspire to the higher standard!

 Got it.
 That's not my point. 
 
 
 
And you keep expecting me to show you OVER and OVER wher polygamy is CONDEMNED in the Bible and I HAVE TOLD YOU I NEVER SAID IT WASN'T. I DON'T DISAGREE WITH YOU THAT IT'S NOT SPECIFICALLY CONDEMNED. Apparently, that has to be spelled out for you verbatim.

 It's funny how you phrase that....
 You "don't disagree with me that it's not specifically condemned".
 As opposed to the more CONCRETE statement of "I agree with you that it's not specifically condemned".
 Was that on purpose?
jyoshu

That would pretty much define the Sodom and Gomorrah pretense that it's about "homosexuality"...
 With the exception that it's the "majority" view.
 Do you condemn people who make that speculation as well?

 
 I haven't "condemned" anyone here for anything (your hyperbole is so noted). I WILL agree with you here that saying the sin of Sodom and Gomorrah was "homosexuality" is incorrect.
 
 
If you give clothes to Goodwill, do you typically wear them to the store to strip right in front of the staff.

 
 A more correct analogy would be to have a good enough friend that one doesn't have a problem changing in front of them. The question should be would have I have problem changing in front of something I considered close as a brother to later give my clothes to goodwill. And the answer is no, if I were that close to someone as a friend I woundn't care.
 
 
You REALLY are not getting the big picture about gays in history, are you...
 It's often "veiled" in some accounts, when other accounts are quite explicit as to what happened.

 
 Not in the books of Samuel though, which is what matters here.
 
 
Did I say David was gay?
 Have you ever heard of "bisexual"?

 
 No you didn't. But Matthew did, I believe. I'll double check.
 
 
Have you ever read some of the posts around here (and other boards) about theories on why people are gay???
 The old "oppressive mother / absent father causes homosexuality" routine?

 
 That's a pretty modern pop-pseudo-psychology take on things. Again, an example of interpreting a 3000-year old account by modern context, IMO.
 
 
I admit that it COULD BE platonic or it COULD BE romantic.

 
 Fair enough, then I admit it COULD be either way as well, though like you I have my views on which it is.
 
 Let's leave it at that and put this ridiculous rabbit chase to bed, shall we?
jyoshu

It's funny how you phrase that....
 You "don't disagree with me that it's not specifically condemned".
 As opposed to the more CONCRETE statement of "I agree with you that it's not specifically condemned".
 Was that on purpose?

 
 
 OMG. 
 
 Foundit, here you go . . . I agree with you that it's not specifically condemned. Happy? You are reading WAAAAY too much into what's not said sometimes.

I haven't "condemned" anyone here for anything (your hyperbole is so noted). I WILL agree with you here that saying the sin of Sodom and Gomorrah was "homosexuality" is incorrect.

 Understood.
 
 
 
A more correct analogy would be to have a good enough friend that one doesn't have a problem changing in front of them. The question should be would have I have problem changing in front of something I considered close as a brother to later give my clothes to goodwill. And the answer is no, if I were that close to someone as a friend I woundn't care.

 Seriously dude.
 If I were to "give" somebody clothing, I wouldn't be WEARING the clothing 10 seconds before I gave it to them.

 emoticon_wow 
 
 
 
Not in the books of Samuel though, which is what matters here.

 According to your opinion...
 
 
 
That's a pretty modern pop-pseudo-psychology take on things. Again, an example of interpreting a 3000-year old account by modern context, IMO.

 Let's leave it at that and put this ridiculous rabbit chase to bed, shall we?
